description:
Fusarium oxysporum NRRL 32931 is a strain of the fungal species Fusarium oxysporum, which belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. Fusarium oxysporum is a soil-borne, plant-pathogenic fungus that can cause wilt diseases in a wide range of crop plants, including tomatoes, bananas, and cotton.

The NRRL 32931 strain was isolated from soil and has been studied for its genetic and physiological characteristics. Like other Fusarium oxysporum strains, NRRL 32931 can produce various secondary metabolites, including mycotoxins, which can be harmful to plants, animals, and humans. The fungus is known to possess the ability to infect plant roots, colonize the vascular system, and disrupt water and nutrient transport, leading to the characteristic symptoms of wilt disease.

Fusarium oxysporum NRRL 32931 has been used in research to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying plant-pathogen interactions, host specificity, and the development of disease resistance strategies. The study of this strain contributes to the broader understanding of Fusarium oxysporum biology and its impact on agricultural and ecological systems.
